title: 105_hr3679
content:
AUTHORIZATIONS OF APPROPRIATIONS FOR UNITED STATES CUSTOMS SERVICE AND IMMIGRATION AND NATURALIZATION SERVICE. Authorized appropriations for the United States Customs Service to enhance border investigative resources, anticorruption efforts, combat drug smuggling and money-laundering, process cargo, reduce traffic waiting times, and open all primary lanes during peak hours at certain ports on the Southwest and Northern borders. Authorized appropriations for the United States Customs Service include $161,248,584 for fiscal year 1999, $185,751,328 for fiscal year 2000, and necessary sums for each fiscal year thereafter. This funding is allocated for salaries, expenses, and equipment to enhance enforcement and inspection resources on the Southwest land border, investigate anticorruption efforts, combat drug smuggling and money-laundering organizations, process cargo, and reduce commercial and passenger traffic. Authorized appropriations for the Immigration and Naturalization Service for fiscal years 1999 and 2000 are $113,604,000 and $121,064,000 respectively. These funds are designated for efforts against drug smuggling and money-laundering organizations, processing cargo, and reducing traffic waiting times at major land border ports of entry on the Southwest and Northern borders of the United States. For fiscal year 1999, $48,404,000 is allocated for the United States Customs Service for acquiring narcotics enforcement and cargo processing technology along the Southwest border. Additional funds are authorized for subsequent fiscal years as needed. For fiscal year 1999, $48,404,000 is allocated for the United States Customs Service for implementing narcotics enforcement and cargo processing technology along the Southwest border. This includes funding for Vehicle and Container Inspection Systems, mobile truck x-rays, upgrade of fixed-site truck x-rays, pallet x-rays, and portable contraband detection. For fiscal year 1999, funding allocations include:
- $7,200,000 for 8 1-MeV pallet x-rays
- $1,000,000 for 200 portable contraband detectors
- $600,000 for 50 contraband detection kits
- $500,000 for 25 ultrasonic container inspection units For fiscal year 1999, funding allocations include:
- $2,450,000 for 7 automated targeting systems
- $360,000 for 30 rapid tire deflator systems
- $480,000 for 20 Portable Treasury Enforcement Communications System (TECS) terminals
- $1,000,000 for 20 remote watch surveillance camera systems For fiscal year 1999, funding allocations include:
- $1,254,000 for 57 weigh-in-motion sensors at ports with high outbound traffic
- $180,000 for 36 AM radio stations at border crossings
- $1,000,000 for 20 remote watch surveillance camera systems at ports with suspicious activities In fiscal year 1999, funding allocations include $180,000 for 36 AM radio stations at border crossings, $1,040,000 for 260 inbound vehicle counters, $950,000 for 38 spotter camera systems to counter surveillance, and $390,000 for 60 inbound commercial truck transponders. In fiscal year 1999, funding allocations include $390,000 for 60 inbound commercial truck transponders, $1,600,000 for 40 narcotics vapor and particle detectors, and $400,000 for license plate reader automatic targeting software at each port. Additionally, $15,090,000 is allocated for acquisition and other expenses for the Immigration and Naturalization Service. In fiscal year 1999, $15,090,000 is allocated for acquisition and other expenses for the Immigration and Naturalization Service, including funding for mobile truck x-rays, ultrasonic container inspection units, and Portable Treasury Enforcement equipment. In fiscal year 1999, funds are allocated for various equipment for border patrol checkpoints, including Portable Treasury Enforcement Communications System terminals, remote watch surveillance camera systems, AM radio stations, and spotter camera systems. In fiscal year 1999, funds are allocated for various equipment for border patrol checkpoints, including Portable Treasury Enforcement Communications System terminals, remote watch surveillance camera systems, AM radio stations, and spotter camera systems. In fiscal year 2000 and thereafter, additional funding is designated for spotter camera systems, narcotics vapor and particle detectors, and other equipment at permanent border patrol checkpoints. For fiscal year 2000 and beyond, funds are allocated for maintenance and support of equipment for the United States Customs Service and the Immigration and Naturalization Service. This includes training personnel and estimating costs for equipment. For fiscal year 2000 and beyond, $1,509,000 is allocated for equipment maintenance and personnel training. The Commissioner of Customs can use funds for technologically superior equipment. For fiscal year 2000 and beyond, $1,509,000 is allocated for equipment maintenance and personnel training. The Commissioner of Customs may reallocate funds for technologically superior equipment that achieves the same results at a lower cost than specified equipment. The Commissioner of Customs has the authority to reallocate up to 10 percent of specified funds for equipment in subsection (b)(1) to other equipment categories. The Attorney General has similar authority for funds and equipment in subsection (b)(2). In addition to the authority granted to the Commissioner of Customs and the Attorney General for reallocating funds for equipment, a specific amount is allocated for hiring additional inspectors and special agents for the Southwest and Northern borders in fiscal years 1999 and 2000. In fiscal years 1999 and 2000, additional inspectors and special agents will be hired for the Southwest and Northern borders to enhance border security and processing efficiency. This includes increasing resources for primary lanes, cargo facilities, and investigative teams. In fiscal years 1999 and 2000, there will be a net increase of 360 special agents and 40 intelligence analysts to combat drug smuggling and money-laundering organizations. Additionally, there will be a net increase of 50 positions and resources for the Office of Internal Affairs to enhance anticorruption efforts. In fiscal years 1999 and 2000, there will be a net increase of 535 inspectors for the Southwest land border and 375 inspectors for the Northern land border to enhance border security. In fiscal years 1999 and 2000, there will be a net increase of 535 inspectors for the Southwest land border and 375 inspectors for the Northern land border to enhance border security. Additionally, there will be a net increase of 100 inspectors and canine enforcement officers for border patrol checkpoints, along with 100 canine enforcement vehicles to reduce waiting times at the Southwest land border. In addition to increasing inspectors and canine enforcement officers at the Southwest and Northern land borders, there will be a net increase of 40 intelligence analysts and additional resources for border patrol sectors targeting drug smuggling and money-laundering organizations. The Office of the Inspector General of the Department of Justice will receive a net increase of 50 positions and additional resources to enhance investigative efforts for anticorruption. The costs incurred due to the increase in personnel hired will also be covered.
